dt: {bc}given to, arising from, or marked by {a_link|despair} {bc}devoid of hope

pt: {sc}despondent{/sc} {sc}despairing{/sc} {sc}desperate{/sc} {sc}hopeless{/sc} mean having lost all or nearly all hope. {sc}despondent{/sc} implies a deep dejection arising from a conviction of the uselessness of further effort.
{sc}despairing{/sc} suggests the slipping away of all hope and often despondency.

pt.t: {it}despairing{/it} appeals for the return of the kidnapped child

pt: {sc}desperate{/sc} implies despair that prompts reckless action or violence in the face of defeat or frustration.

pt.t: one last {it}desperate{/it} attempt to turn the tide of battle

pt: {sc}hopeless{/sc} suggests despair and the cessation of effort or resistance and often implies acceptance or resignation.

pt.t: the situation of the trapped miners is {it}hopeless{/it}

shortdef: given to, arising from, or marked by despair : devoid of hope

quotes.t: It is possible that at this stage Caesar had not altogether {qword}despaired{/qword} of a consensual solution to the difficulties facing the Republic.
Yet, until very recently, Alzheimer's was so poorly understood that scientists {qword}despaired{/qword} of finding a treatment, much less a cure.
Sometimes it is hard not to {qword}despair{/qword} about relations between men and women in American society. They seem to have hit rock bottom.

et: Middle English {it}despeiren, despairen, dispairen{/it} "to lose hope or confidence, be discouraged," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}despeir-,{/it} tonic stem of {it}desperer,{/it} going back to Latin {it}dēspērāre{/it} "to give up as hopeless, despair of," from {it}dē-{/it} {et_link|de-|de-} + {it}spērāre{/it} "to look forward to, hope for, hope (that)," verbal derivative of {it}*spēs-,{/it} presumed alternate stem of {it}spēs, spem{/it} {ldquo}hope, expectation{rdquo} perhaps by analogy with {it}vīr-, vīs{/it} {ldquo}strength, force{rdquo} {ma}{mat|speed:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to lose all hope or confidence
